item.title: Using worked examples supports novices to develop their programming practice
item.description: Worked examples demonstrate an ‘expert’ solution to a problem and are used in many subjects to support novices, who use the examples as blueprints for solving new but related problems.

item.title: Pair programming supports learners to produce better solutions to complex programming problems
item.description: Pair programming is a pedagogical approach that you can use in your classroom which involves learners working together on a problem to develop programs.

item.title: Using peer instruction in lessons helps students learn, retain, and discuss computing concepts
item.description: Peer instruction (PI) is an instructional technique first proposed in the 1990s by Eric Mazur,1 whose research demonstrated the benefits of focused discussion for pupils’ understanding and retention in physics.

item.title: Live coding: using the thought processes of a programmer to bring coding to life
item.description: When learners read static, completed programs, they aren’t exposed to the troubleshooting that has already taken place to get to that end product; this is known as being product focused.

item.title: Improving explanations and learning activities in computing using semantic waves
item.description: Semantic waves’ describe an ideal conceptual journey for novice learners to follow, shifting between expert and novice understanding, abstract and concrete context, and technical and simple meanings.

item.title: Using concept maps to capture, communicate, construct, and assess knowledge
item.description: Concept maps are “graphical tools for organising and representing knowledge”.1 Fundamentally, they consist of concepts and the labelled links between them, which together describe knowledge in the form of statements or propositions.

item.title: Planning and reflecting on distance learning in the context of 'emergency remote teaching'
item.description: The exceptional events of 2020 have dramatically altered the way that education is delivered to students around the world.

item.title: Planning effective surveys and interviews for research or evaluation
item.description: Surveys and interviews are common tools used by researchers to understand participants’ perceptions, attitudes, and feelings.

item.title: Using observation techniques to record student behaviour for research or evaluation
item.description: Classroom action research is an effective approach that teachers can use to embed evidence-based pedagogies into their practice.
